DOC.HEAD: Fighting Around TV Station Underlines TV's Role In Uprising
Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with bloody faces in TV studio, grenades hitting TV building. Pickup 7th graf, `As today's...'
DOC.TEXT: Romania's uprising turned into a battle for the airwaves today, as members of ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's despised security forces tried to retake national television and radio stations. National television showed the bloody faces of some people crowding one of its studios after apparently fleeing the fighting outside. The provisional government formed after army units joined the masses in toppling Ceausescu on Friday, appealed for help. ``Army units and citizens we need you,'' a Bucharest radio announcer implored. ``Block off the radio-television area.'' Machine-gun fire and the sound of light tank shells filled the air and tracers crossed the smoky skyline outside the government TV building at dawn in a firefight between army units and Ceausescu loyalists. The attackers appeared mostly to be in surrounding apartment buildings. Bullets and rocket-propelled grenades hit the TV building, and a TV announcer reported without elaborating that injuries resulted. As today's firefight started, Marin Constantin, normally editor of youth programs, took charge of herding staff and visitors into hallways, away from windows. ``Safe here, halfway,'' he said, noting the eighth floor was a safe compromise between first and 13th. He seized a wooden chair and smashed a ceiling light to darken the corridor. Gratiela Ripeanu, who normally handles visitors and external relations for the TV station, chuckled as the noise grew deafening. ``Are you a war correspondent?'' she chided a colleague far more used to reporting on rallies and government communiques. A MiG fighter jet flew low overhead, and TV reporters said it was in a dogfight with diehard units. But that could not be independently confirmed. The new army-backed leadership on Friday used the newly captured TV to broadcast demonstrations nationwide and propose new elections next year. Ceausescu's son, Nicu, was shown with a bloody face after he was arrested. About 2:30 a.m. today, Ceausescu loyalists in the security forces tried to seize radio and TV headquarters _ about two miles apart _ and were beaten back. Then they counterattacked. The TV station stayed on the air during the first attack, with reporter Victor Ionesco exhorting residents of Bucharest to come to scene of the shooting. ``Come help us,'' he implored. ``We're helping you.'' People who had been chanting outside the TV building only minutes before the shooting scattered briefly during the attack, but they came back and cheered when tanks on side of the uprising took up new positions around the building. A crowd of about 3,000 people then took up a vigil through the night outside the building, continuing their chants for liberty.
